member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Caches.PathsChangeMonitor.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases all managed and unmanaged resources and any references to the System.Runtime.Caching.ChangeMonitor instance. This overload must be implemented by derived change-monitor classes.
member.param: True to release managed and unmanaged resources and any references to a System.Runtime.Caching.ChangeMonitor instance; false to release only unmanaged resources. When false is passed, the System.Runtime.Caching.ChangeMonitor.Dispose(System.Boolean) method is called by a finalizer thread and any external managed references are likely no longer valid because they have already been garbage collected.

member.summary: sort order for search result.

member.name: T:Newegg.Framework.Configuration.ConfigurationManagerBase
member.summary: Deserialize the configuration file into a runtime object, and monitors the configuration file and reflects any change to the runtime object as well.
member.remarks: Note to the extenders: Future work: currently, configuration manager relies on System.Web.Caching.Cache to manage configuration objects. MS enterprise library caching component is not used because filedependecy checks file's date every time an cache item is accessed and thus impose too much IO operations. System.Web.Caching.Cache supports many features and is therefore used here. This, however, restricts the future scalablity and usage scenarios of this component cause the consumer will have to be dependent on System.Web.dll. Solution: implement a custome filedependy for MS enterprise library that uses FileSystemWatcher to get notification of file changes rather than actively checking file dates and thus reduces IO operation.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Configuration.ConfigurationManagerBase.LoadConfiguration``1(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: if serialization fails, an exception is thrown.
member.exception: when configuration file fails to load

member.summary: Add configuration to cache
member.param: section name defined in the web.config

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Configuration.ConfigurationManagerBase.GetFromCache``1(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Get configuration object from cache. If the underlying file changes, the object will be reloaded.
member.param: file name of the configuration object
member.returns: configuration object
member.exception: when configuration file fails to load

member.summary: Gets the current working directory of the application.
member.returns: A string that contains the path of the current working directory, and does not end with a backslash (\).
member.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
The operating system is Windows CE, which does not have current directory functionality.This method is available in the .NET Compact Framework, but is not currently supported.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticDirectory.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the given path refers to an existing directory on disk.
member.returns: True if path refers to an existing directory; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticDirectory.GetDirectories(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the names of subdirectories (including their paths) in the specified directory.
member.param: The path for which an array of subdirectory names is returned.
member.returns: An array of the full names (including paths) of subdirectories in the specified path.
member.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
Path is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters as defined by System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
Path is null.

The specified path, file name, or both exceed the system-defined maximum length. For example, on Windows-based platforms, paths must be less than 248 characters and file names must be less than 260 characters.
Path is a file name.
The specified path is invalid (for example, it is on an unmapped drive).

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticDirectory.GetDirectories(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Gets the names of subdirectories (including their paths) that match the specified search pattern in the current directory.
member.param: The search string to match against the names of files in path. The parameter cannot end in two periods ("..") or contain two periods ("..") followed by System.IO.Path.DirectorySeparatorChar or System.IO.Path.AltDirectorySeparatorChar, nor can it contain any of the characters in System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
member.returns: An array of the full names (including paths) of the subdirectories that match the search pattern.
member.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
Path is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters as defined by System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
Path or searchPattern is null.

The specified path, file name, or both exceed the system-defined maximum length. For example, on Windows-based platforms, paths must be less than 248 characters and file names must be less than 260 characters.
Path is a file name.
The specified path is invalid (for example, it is on an unmapped drive).

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticDirectory.GetDirectories(System.String,System.String,System.IO.SearchOption)
member.summary: Gets the names of the subdirectories (including their paths) that match the specified search pattern in the current directory, and optionally searches subdirectories.
member.param: The search string to match against the names of files in path. The parameter cannot end in two periods ("..") or contain two periods ("..") followed by System.IO.Path.DirectorySeparatorChar or System.IO.Path.AltDirectorySeparatorChar, nor can it contain any of the characters in System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
One of the enumeration values that specifies whether the search operation should include all subdirectories or only the current directory.
member.returns: An array of the full names (including paths) of the subdirectories that match the search pattern.
member.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
Path is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters as defined by System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
Path or searchPattern is null.

The specified path, file name, or both exceed the system-defined maximum length. For example, on Windows-based platforms, paths must be less than 248 characters and file names must be less than 260 characters.
Path is a file name.
The specified path is invalid (for example, it is on an unmapped drive).

member.summary: Gets the names of the subdirectories (including their paths) that match the specified search pattern in the current directory, and optionally searches subdirectories.

The parameter cannot end in two periods ("..") or contain two periods ("..") followed by System.IO.Path.DirectorySeparatorChar or System.IO.Path.AltDirectorySeparatorChar, nor can it contain any of the characters in System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
One of the enumeration values that specifies whether the search operation should include all subdirectories or only the current directory.
member.returns: An array of the full names (including paths) of the subdirectories that match the search pattern.
member.exception: The caller does not have the required permission.
Path is a zero-length string, contains only white space, or contains one or more invalid characters as defined by System.IO.Path.InvalidPathChars.
Path or searchPattern is null.

The specified path, file name, or both exceed the system-defined maximum length. For example, on Windows-based platforms, paths must be less than 248 characters and file names must be less than 260 characters.

The specified path is invalid (for example, it is on an unmapped drive).

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticFile.Exists(System.String)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified file exists.
member.returns: true if the caller has the required permissions and path contains the name of an existing file; otherwise, false. This method also returns false if path is null, an invalid path, or a zero-length string. If the caller does not have sufficient permissions to read the specified file, no exception is thrown and the method returns false regardless of the existence of path.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticPath.GetExtension(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the extension of the specified path string.
member.param: The path string from which to get the extension.
member.returns: The extension of the specified path (including the period "."), or null, or System.String.Empty. If path is null, System.IO.Path.GetExtension(System.String) returns null. If path does not have extension information, System.IO.Path.GetExtension(System.String) returns System.String.Empty.
member.exception: Path contains one or more of the invalid characters defined in System.IO.Path.GetInvalidPathChars().

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.IO.IStaticPath.GetFileName(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the file name and extension of the specified path string.
member.param: The path string from which to obtain the file name and extension.
member.returns: The characters after the last directory character in path. If the last character of path is a directory or volume separator character, this method returns System.String.Empty. If path is null, this method returns null.
member.exception: Path contains one or more of the invalid characters defined in System.IO.Path.GetInvalidPathChars().

member.summary: Returns the file name of the specified path string without the extension.
member.returns: The string returned by System.IO.Path.GetFileName(System.String), minus the last period (.) and all characters following it.
member.exception: Path contains one or more of the invalid characters defined in System.IO.Path.GetInvalidPathChars().

member.name: T:Newegg.Framework.Threading.HybridContextStorage
member.summary: Implements by using both and and choosing dynamically between them.
member.remarks:
In web applications a single Request may be executed on different threads. In this case HttpContext.Current is the only invariant.
This implementation dynamically chooses between System.Runtime.Remoting.Messaging.CallContext and System.Web.HttpContext to store data.

member.name: T:Newegg.Framework.Threading.LogicalThreadContext
member.summary: An abstraction to safely store "ThreadStatic" data.
member.remarks:
By default, is used to store thread-specific data. You may switch the storage strategy by calling .
NOTE: Access to the underlying storage is not synchronized for performance reasons. You should call only once at application startup!

member.name: F:Newegg.Framework.Threading.LogicalThreadContext.threadStorage
member.summary: Holds the current strategy.
member.remarks: Access to this variable is not synchronized on purpose for performance reasons. Setting a different strategy should happen only once at application startup.

member.name: T:Newegg.Framework.Utility.AntiXssEncoder
member.summary:
AntiXssEncoder can be used to provide additional protection to ASP.NET Web-based applications against Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) attacks.
To provide this protection, the library first defines a set of valid characters such as a-z and A-Z and automatically encodes any characters not defined in that valid set (invalid characters or potential attack characters). This technique is commonly referred to as the principle of inclusions and can provide advantages over other techniques. Cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks exploit vulnerabilities in Web-based applications that fail to properly validate and/or encode input that is embedded in response data. Malicious users can then inject client-side script into response data causing the unsuspecting user's browser to execute the script code. The script code will appear to have originated from a trusted-site and may be able to bypass browser protection mechanisms such as security zones. These attacks are platform and browser independent, and can allow malicious users to perform malicious actions such as gaining unauthorized access to client data like cookies or hijacking sessions entirely.
Simple steps that developers can take to prevent XSS attacks in their ASP.NET applications include (see How To: Prevent Cross-Site Scripting in ASP.NET in the Patterns & Practices series for more detail):
Validating and constraining input
Encoding output
To properly use the Microsoft Anti-Cross Site Scripting Library to protect their ASP.NET Web-applications, developers need to:
Step 1: Review ASP.NET code that generates output
Step 2: Determine whether output includes un-trusted input parameters
Step 3: Determine the context which the un-trusted input is used as output
Step 4: Encode output
Step 1: Review ASP.NET Code that Generates Output XSS attacks are dependent on the ability of un-trusted input to be embedded as output, and so code that generates output must first be identified. Some common vectors include calls to Response.Write and ASP <% = calls.
Step 2: Determine if Output Could Contain Un-Trusted Input Once the sections of code that generate output have been identified, they should be analysed to determined if the output may contain un-trusted input such as input from users or from some other un-trusted source. If the output does contain un-trusted input then that un-trusted input will require encoding. Some common sources of un-trusted input include:
Application variables
Cookies
Databases
Form fields
Query string variables
Session variables
If it is uncertain that the output may contain un-trusted input, then it is best to err on the side of caution and encode the output anyways.
Step 3: Determine Encoding Method to Use
Encoding Method Description
HtmlEncode Encodes input strings for use in HTML
HtmlAttributeEncode Encodes input strings for use in HTML attributes
JavaScriptEncode Encodes input strings for use in JavaScript
UrlEncode Encodes input strings for use in Universal Resource Locators (URLs)
XmlEncode Encodes input strings for use in XML
XmlAttributeEncode Encodes input strings for use in XML attributes
Step 4: Encode Output

member.name: T:Newegg.Framework.Utility.ArrayUtils
member.summary: Various utility methods relating to the manipulation of arrays.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Utility.ArrayUtils.HasLength(System.Collections.ICollection)
member.summary: Checks if the given array or collection is null or has no elements.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Utility.ArrayUtils.AreEqual(System.Array,System.Array)
member.summary: Tests equality of two single-dimensional arrays by checking each element for equality.
member.param: The first array to be checked.
The second array to be checked.
member.returns: True if arrays are the same, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Utility.ArrayUtils.GetHashCode(System.Array)
member.summary: Returns hash code for an array that is generated based on the elements.
member.remarks: Hash code returned by this method is guaranteed to be the same for arrays with equal elements.
member.param: Array to calculate hash code for.
member.returns: A hash code for the specified array.

member.name: M:Newegg.Framework.Utility.ArrayUtils.ToString(System.Array)
member.summary: Returns string representation of an array.
member.param: Array to return as a string.
member.returns: String representation of the specified .
